fields.headline: Alive languages
fields.bodyText: Look We Have Coming to Dover! Written and read by Daljit Nagra Faber 60min £12.99 In startlingly newly minted language, with cracking vigour and wicked humour, this collection (which won the 2007 Forward Prize) explores the experience of a second-generation British Punjabi. The contradictory feelings of dislocation, assimilation and alienation in this 'flighty mix-up country' are emphasised by the shifts of language from Punjabi English - 'She effing at my mum / in all di colours of Punjabi' - to regional and formal English. Nagra's licence with language is invigorating - how could you better describe the first flush of married life than 'Darling is so pirouetty with us / for whirlwind married month'? The poet's reading, like his words, is energetic and as alive as quicksilver. Wahay Guru!
